title: Mycorrhizosphere
text:
The mycorrhizosphere is the region around a <a href="mycorrhiza">mycorrhiza</a>l fungus in which nutrients released from the fungus increase the microbial population and its activities. The roots of most terrestrial plants, including most <a href="crop">crop</a> plants and almost all <a href="woody%20plant">woody plant</a>s, are colonized by mycorrhiza-forming <a href="symbiosis">symbiotic</a> fungi. In this relationship, the plant roots are infected by a fungus, but the rest of the fungal <a href="mycelium">mycelium</a> continues to grow through the soil, digesting and absorbing nutrients and water and sharing these with its plant <a href="host%20%28biology%29">host</a>. The fungus in turn benefits by receiving <a href="photosynthesis">photosynthetic</a> sugars from its host. The mycorrhizosphere consists of roots, <a href="hypha">hypha</a>e of the directly connected mycorrhizal fungi, associated microorganisms, and the soil in their direct influence.
Organisms involved.
The mycorrhizosphere involves a community of microorganisms. There are three <a href="division%20%28mycology%29">divisions</a> of fungi that can form mycorrhizae, the <a href="Glomeromycota">Glomeromycota</a>, <a href="Ascomycota">Ascomycota</a>, and <a href="Basidiomycota">Basidiomycota</a>. Glomeromycota can form <a href="arbuscular%20mycorrhiza">arbuscular mycorrhiza</a>e with <a href="angiosperm">angiosperm</a>s (flowering plants), <a href="gymnosperm">gymnosperm</a>s (seed-producing plants), <a href="pteridophyte">pteridophyte</a>s, <a href="moss">moss</a>es, <a href="lycopod">lycopod</a>s, and <a href="Psilotales">Psilotales</a>. Ascomycota fungi form <a href="ericoid%20mycorrhiza">ericoid mycorrhiza</a>s with plants of the order <a href="Ericales">Ericales</a>, and ectomycorrhizas with trees. Basidiomycota fungi form ecto-, <a href="Orchid%20mycorrhizae">orchid</a>, monotropoid, arbutoid, and some ericoid mycorrhizae. Fungal hyphae are thinner than plant roots, which allows them to penetrate areas in the soil with moisture and nutrient that are inaccessible to roots. In some cases, mycorrhizal fungi in the mycorrhizosphere may ward off fungal <a href="plant%20pathogen">plant pathogen</a>s. For example, the arbuscular mycorrhizal fungus "<a href="Glomus%20intraradices">Glomus intraradices</a>" reduces <a href="germination">germination</a> of the pathogen "<a href="Fusarium%20oxysporum">Fusarium oxysporum</a>", but stimulates germination of a non-pathogenic fungus "<a href="Trichoderma%20harzianum">Trichoderma harzianum</a>".
Soil <a href="bacteria">bacteria</a> in the mycorrhizosphere influence plant growth in several ways: by affecting the uptake of nutrients, providing protection against pathogens, contributing to <a href="nitrogen%20fixation">nitrogen fixation</a>, and contributing to <a href="mineral%20weathering">mineral weathering</a>. <a href="Archaea">Archaea</a> are also known to exist in mycorrhizosphere. They may contribute to nitrogen fixation and produce antibiotic compounds, but the extent of their interactions with other organisms and their overall function is not well known. Soil <a href="protozoa">protozoa</a> feed on bacteria, and, in some cases, hyphae. The type of mycorrhizae greatly influences the protozoal population in a mycorrhizosphere. For example, a "<a href="Paxillus%20involutus">Paxillus involutus</a>"–<a href="conifer">conifer</a> mycorrhiza seems to reduce the density of protozoa in the resulting mycorrhizosphere, but mycorrhizae formed with "<a href="Lactarius%20rufus">Lactarius rufus</a>" and "<a href="Suillus%20bovinus">Suillus bovinus</a>" have the opposite effect. Other soil organisms that influence the mycorrhizosphere community include soil animals such as <a href="nematode">nematode</a>s, <a href="mite">mite</a>s, and <a href="earthworm">earthworm</a>s, which forage on roots, hyphae and their associated microorganisms.
